title: Judgment on Jerusalem
shortSummary: Isaiah chapter 3 pronounces God's judgment on Jerusalem and Judah for their rebellion and pride. The chapter describes the removal of leadership and provision, the rise of immature rulers, and the consequences of sin including social disorder and divine punishment. It serves as a sober warning about the consequences of forsaking God and living in pride and injustice.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - During the reign of King Ahaz of Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The capital city of Judah, representing the people of God who face judgment for their sins.

keyCharacters.name: Judah
keyCharacters.description: The southern kingdom of Israel, whose leaders and people are condemned for their rebellion and pride.

keyCharacters.name: Children and Babes
keyCharacters.description: Symbolic of immature and unfit rulers who will lead the people due to the removal of wise leadership.

keyCharacters.name: Daughters of Zion
keyCharacters.description: Refers to the women of Jerusalem who are condemned for their haughtiness and vanity.

definitions.definition: Metaphors for support and stability, referring to leaders and provisions essential for the wellbeing of the people.
A phrase indicating that inexperienced and immature individuals will be placed in authority, leading to chaos.
A skin disease used symbolically here to represent divine punishment and shame.
The sound of ornaments or jewelry, symbolizing vanity and pride in outward appearance.

outline.heading: Removal of Support and Leadership
outline.description: God announces He will remove the essential supports of Jerusalem and Judah, including leaders and provisions, resulting in social chaos and immature rulers.

outline.heading: Social Disorder and Rebellion
outline.description: The people turn against one another, refusing to lead or be led, highlighting the breakdown of social order and the rise of unfit rulers.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment Against Leaders
outline.description: The LORD stands to judge the elders and princes for their exploitation and injustice toward the poor, emphasizing accountability before God.

outline.heading: Condemnation of the Prideful Women
outline.description: The daughters of Zion are rebuked for their pride and vanity, and God declares He will remove their ornaments and bring shame upon them.

outline.heading: The Consequences of Judgment
outline.description: The chapter closes with a vivid picture of destruction and mourning as the city’s men fall in battle and the gates lament in desolation.

application: Trust in God as the true source of stability and provision rather than relying on human leaders or material wealth.
Recognize the dangers of pride and vanity, seeking humility and godly character instead of outward appearance.
Submit to God’s righteous judgment and repent from injustice, especially in how we treat others.
Pray for wise and godly leadership in the church and society, and be willing to follow those who lead according to God’s Word.

keyVerses.text: And I will give children to be their princes, and babes shall rule over them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the consequence of God removing mature leadership, resulting in immature rulers and social instability.

keyVerses.text: Say ye to the righteous, that it shall be well with him: for they shall eat the fruit of their doings.
keyVerses.significance: A promise of blessing and reward for the righteous, encouraging faithfulness and obedience to God.

keyVerses.text: Woe unto the wicked! it shall be ill with him: for the reward of his hands shall be given him.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn warning that the wicked will face the consequences of their sinful actions, underscoring divine justice.

keyVerses.text: Moreover the LORD saith, Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with stretched forth necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go, and making a tinkling with their feet:
keyVerses.significance: This verse condemns pride and vanity, especially among the women of Jerusalem, illustrating how sin leads to judgment.
